content:
FALSE. The 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup was not co-hosted by Germany and France; it was co-hosted by Australia and New Zealand[1][2][3]. Germany hosted the tournament in 2011, and France was the host nation in 2019[4].

## 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup Host Details

The ninth edition of the FIFA Women's World Cup took place from 20 July to 20 August 2023, across Australia and New Zealand[1][6]. This tournament marked several historic firsts:
*   **First Co-Hosted Women's World Cup**: It was the first time the FIFA Women's World Cup was hosted by more than one nation[1][7].
*   **First in Southern Hemisphere**: The event was the first Women's World Cup held in the Southern Hemisphere[1][8].
*   **First Across Confederations**: It was the first FIFA senior tournament hosted across two different confederations, as Australia is part of the Asian Football Confederation (AFC) and New Zealand is in the Oceanian Football Confederation (OFC)[1][3][9].
*   **First with 32 Teams**: The tournament was expanded from 24 to 32 participating national teams[3][6].

### Host Selection Process

On 25 June 2020, FIFA announced that the joint bid from Australia and New Zealand had won the hosting rights[1]. The decision was made by the FIFA Council via a vote where the Australia-New Zealand bid received 22 votes, defeating the bid from Colombia, which received 13 votes[1][10]. Japan and Brazil had also submitted bids but withdrew before the final vote.

### Tournament Venues

A total of 64 matches were played across ten stadiums in nine host cities[11][12].

**Australian Host Cities & Stadiums**[8][13]:
*   Adelaide (Hindmarsh Stadium)
*   Brisbane (Lang Park / Brisbane Stadium)
*   Melbourne (Melbourne Rectangular Stadium)
*   Perth (Perth Rectangular Stadium)
*   Sydney (Stadium Australia and Sydney Football Stadium)

**New Zealand Host Cities & Stadiums**[8][13]:
*   Auckland (Eden Park)
*   Dunedin (Forsyth Barr Stadium)
*   Hamilton (Waikato Stadium)
*   Wellington (Wellington Regional Stadium)

The opening match featuring co-host New Zealand against Norway was held at Eden Park in Auckland, while the final match, where Spain defeated England, took place at Stadium Australia in Sydney[6][11][14].
